installationPage.title: Installation
installationPage.installCommand: Run the following command to install
installationPage.gettingStarted: Get started with KubeStellar by setting up your development environment. Follow our guided installation process to deploy your demo system.

sidebarSteps.title: Installation Steps
sidebarSteps.description: Follow these steps to set up KubeStellar
sidebarSteps.checkPrerequisitesDescription: Ensure you have all the required tools installed
sidebarSteps.installKubestellarDescription: Deploy KubeStellar using the CLI commands
sidebarSteps.startUsingKubestellarDescription: Log in and begin managing your clusters

prerequisites.title: System Prerequisites
prerequisites.description: Ensure these tools are installed before proceeding

installation.title: Install KubeStellar
installation.description: Choose your platform and run the installation script

installPrerequisitesFirst.title: Install Prerequisites First
installPrerequisitesFirst.description: Before running the installation script, ensure you have all the required prerequisites installed on your system.

installation.scriptInstructions: Run this command in your terminal to install KubeStellar with

installationProcess.title: Installation Process:
steps: Sets up proper networking and permissions

importantNotes.title: Important Notes:
notes: Installation may take several minutes to complete
Ensure you have sufficient system resources available
Keep the terminal window open until installation finishes
Check the terminal output for any error messages

afterInstallation.title: After Installation:
steps: Verify the installation by checking cluster status

checkingStatus.title: Checking KubeStellar installation status...
checkingStatus.description: This should only take a moment. We're checking if KubeStellar is already installed on your system.

checkError.title: Status Check Failed
checkError.description: Unable to check if KubeStellar is installed. This could be due to a connection issue with the backend service or the server may be temporarily unavailable.
checkError.persistenceNote: If the problem persists, please check your network connection or contact your system administrator.

footer.description: KubeStellar is an open-source project. For support, feature requests, or bug reports, please visit our GitHub repository.

skipPrerequisitesNotice.title: Prerequisites Check Skipped
skipPrerequisitesNotice.description: Prerequisites check has been disabled in this environment. You can proceed directly to installation.
skipPrerequisitesNotice.note: Note: Ensure you have installed all required tools manually before running the installation commands.

toasts.alreadyInstalled: KubeStellar is already installed! Redirecting to login...
toasts.notInstalled: Kubeflex cluster not found. Follow steps to set up KubeStellar environment.
toasts.followInstructions: Follow the CLI installation instructions below to install KubeStellar
toasts.loadInstructionsFailed: Failed to load installation instructions. Please refresh the page and try again.
toasts.installationDetected: KubeStellar installation detected! Redirecting to login page...

dashboard.title: Dashboard
dashboard.hoverFormula: Hover to see the formula breakdown
dashboard.welcome: Welcome to the KubeStellar management dashboard

pods.calculation: Calculated based on the ratio of healthy pods to total pods across all namespaces.
pods.status: Factors in pod status, readiness probes, and liveness checks
pods.value: Higher values indicate better cluster health

cpu.calculation: Calculated as the percentage of allocated CPU resources currently in use across all nodes in the cluster.
cpu.value: Lower values indicate better resource availability

memory.calculation: Calculated as the percentage of allocated memory resources currently in use across all nodes in the cluster.
memory.value: Lower values indicate better resource availability

guide.title: Dashboard Guide
guide.clusterStatsDesc: Shows total and active clusters. Hover over metrics to see detailed information about how they're calculated.
guide.healthMetricsDesc: Displays CPU, memory usage, and pod health. Green indicators show good health, amber requires attention.
guide.recentActivityDesc: Shows recent changes to clusters and policies. Click on a cluster to view detailed information.
guide.proTipDesc: Hover over any metric or chart to see detailed information about how it's calculated and what actions you can take.

detach.title: Detach Cluster
detach.confirmation: Are you sure you want to detach the following cluster?
detach.warning: Warning: This action will remove the cluster from management. It will no longer be visible or controlled from this interface.

noClusters.title: No Ready Clusters
noClusters.description: No clusters are currently available for binding. You need to have at least one cluster in "Ready" state before creating binding policies.

noWorkloads.title: No Workloads Found
noWorkloads.description: No workloads are available. Please ensure you have access to workloads.

noResources.title: No Clusters or Workloads Found
noResources.description: You need both clusters and workloads to create binding policies.

noPolicies.title: No Binding Policies Found
noPolicies.description: Get started by creating your first binding policy

dragDrop.infoAlert: This interface is using simulated responses to create binding policies. Select clusters and workloads from the lists to add them to the canvas, then click on a workload and then a cluster to create a binding policy connection.

helpDialog.title: Create Binding Policies with Direct Connections
helpDialog.intro: Follow these steps to create binding policies:

steps.selectClusters: 1. Select clusters from the left panel to include in the canvas
steps.selectWorkloads: 2. Select workloads from the right panel to include in the canvas
steps.createConnection: 3. Click on a workload first, then a cluster to create a direct connection
steps.fillDetails: 4. Fill in the policy details in the dialog that appears
steps.deploy: 5. Use the 'Deploy Binding Policies' button to simulate deployment

helpDialog.title: How to Create Binding Policies
helpDialog.intro: Follow these steps to create binding policies:

steps.selectLabels: 1. Select labels to add to the canvas
steps.selectLabelsDesc: Click on clusters from the left panel and workloads from the right panel to add them to the binding policy canvas
steps.deployDesc: Click 'Deploy Binding Policies' to create and deploy binding policies that connect workloads to clusters based on the selected labels

helpDialog.tip: Tip: The label-based approach allows you to create powerful binding policies that automatically apply to all resources matching the selected labels, both now and in the future.

messages.invalidPolicyNames: Error: Some selected policy names are invalid
messages.partialDeleteSuccess: Deleted {{success}} policies, but failed to delete {{failures}} policies

editDialog.title: Edit Binding Policy
editDialog.info: Edit your binding policy configuration. Changes will be applied after saving.
editDialog.name: Binding Policy Name
editDialog.unsavedInfo: You have unsaved changes. Are you sure you want to close without saving?

deleteDialog.title: Delete Binding Policy
deleteDialog.confirm: Are you sure you want to delete the binding policy "{{name}}"? This action cannot be undone.

header.searchPlaceholder: Search policies by name, label or status

availableItems.title: Available Items

availableItems.clickToAdd: Click an item to add it to the canvas

policyNameDialog.title: Name Your Binding Policy
policyNameDialog.invalid: Name must be lowercase alphanumeric with hyphens, max 253 characters
policyNameDialog.helper: Use lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens only
policyNameDialog.namingTips: Use descriptive names like "frontend-to-production" or "database-sync-policy" for better organization.

configureDialog.title: Configure Binding Policy
configureDialog.creatingForDesc: This will create a binding policy that links the {{sourceType}} to the {{targetType}}.
configureDialog.updateStrategyHelper: Select how changes to resources should be applied to clusters. Add clusters and workloads by selecting them from the panels.
configureDialog.labelsTooltip: Labels help identify and select resources
configureDialog.schedulingTooltip: Define conditions that must be met for a cluster to receive this workload
configureDialog.noSchedulingRules: No scheduling rules added. The policy will apply to all matching clusters regardless of their resources.
configureDialog.yamlPreviewInfo: This is a preview of the YAML that will be applied. You can make changes in the other tabs to update this preview.

label.title: Workload Label *
label.helpText: Workload label is key:value pair. Key is constant and defaulted to 'kubestellar.io/workload', you can only change the value.

troubleshooting.title: Try these troubleshooting steps:
troubleshooting.step1: 1. Check that the backend server is running at http://localhost:4000
troubleshooting.step2: 2. Verify the server's CORS configuration allows requests from http://localhost:5173
troubleshooting.step3: 3. If the server uses wildcard (*) CORS, it can't accept requests with credentials
troubleshooting.step4: 4. Check the browser console for detailed error messages
